_exec_summary.SummaryText:
, the refinery has its own 24-hour fire department, staffed by trained full-time fire fighters.  Fire fighters and emergency medical technicians are on site 24 hours per day, equipped to provide rapid first response to an incident.  In addition, the refinery has an emergency response plan, and works closely with the El Segundo Fire Department on the response to fires or releases, public sheltering, and the coordination of other support service providers such as police or paramedics.  The main city fire station is approximately half of a mile from the facility gate. 

1.2	The Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled

Toxic Substances

This RMP includes two toxic substances: anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia.

Ammonia is generated in the normal course of refining petroleum in order to remove nitrogen from the crude oil. The removal of the nitrogen with hydrogen produces ammonia. The ammonia is first collected from the process in streams of water called sour water. The ammonia is then removed as gaseous anhydrous ammonia from the sour water by distillation. A major percentage of the cleaned water can then be re-used in the refining process, thus reducing fresh water consumption.

Flammables

The refinery contains a large amount of flammable substances subject to the RMP. These range from the smallest compounds such as methane to larger ones such as pentane. Practically any process unit in the facility contains these substances in various mixtures. Since the process units and storage vessels vary in the composition of flammables present, each was looked at separately. 

1.3	RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis

This section describes the worst-case release and alternative case release scenarios for the toxic and flammable substances at the facility.

A worst-case release is defined by the EPA as a release of the entire largest single-point quantity in a scenario that would create the largest offsite consequence under worst-case atmos

1.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This document describes the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Chevron El Segundo Refinery. As the name implies, it provides a discussion of several key hazardous substances stored or used at the refinery, describes the potential hazards they pose, and outlines Chevron's programs aimed at preventing major, unexpected releases of these substances into the surrounding community.  

The evolution of these programs deserves some explanation. The El Segundo Refinery began operations in 1911 making kerosene and other products. Since that time, the products and processes have expanded to include the making of gasoline, jet, diesel and other petroleum-based products. The refinery is a major supplier of automotive gasoline to LA basin users and jet fuel to LAX. 

Over the last 60 years or more, the government passed various laws regulating industrial air pollution and the prevention of major releases at the federal and state levels. One of these laws at the federal level was the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 (CAA). The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) is charged with overseeing the implementation of Section 112(r) of the CAA, which regulates major unexpected releases from facilities such as refineries. The EPA requires regulated facilities to prepare and submit Risk Management Plans.  The refinery submitted its first federal RMP to the USEPA and to the El Segundo Fire Department in 1999.  Since the 1999 version, we have submitted all required corrections and resubmissions per the RMP regulations.

The Chevron El Segundo RMP includes information regarding three federally regulated substances: anhydrous ammonia; aqueous ammonia; and flammables. The CAA also provides for public communication of this RMP to establish dialog between facilities and the surrounding community concerning the risks associated with the facility. Public meetings, sponsored by Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER), were conducted in El Segundo, Ma

nhattan Beach, and Hawthorne. 

It should be noted that the refinery also handles other toxic substances that are not addressed in this document, even though the general refinery prevention programs do address them. The refinery is available to discuss its hazardous substances or the contents of this document with community members at (310) 615-5000 during business hours. During off-hours, community information requests or concerns should be directed to (310) 615-5342 .

The Environmental Protection Agency has listed specific elements to include in an RMP executive summary (40 CFR Part 68).  The remainder of this summary follows a straight format that mirrors the agency's list.


1.1	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

One of the key purposes of the prevention program is to establish a process safety system in facilities.  Process safety is a before-the-fact accident prevention system with its foundations at the earliest stages of equipment design, maintenance and operation. The refinery routinely analyzes hazards and safeguards, and takes pro-active steps to ensure that incidents are prevented or that the consequences of an unlikely event are mitigated. Chevron El Segundo first established a Process Safety Management (PSM) program in the early 1990s as part of its OSHA compliance efforts. The EPA recognizes this OSHA mandated program in the RMP regulations. This PSM program encompasses the following, and other, elements:

¿	Training facility operators with regard to the safe handling of flammable and toxic substances;
¿	Performing hazards analyses on new and existing plants at periodic intervals;
¿	Ensuring that operating procedures, manuals and engineering information on the facility are kept up to date;
¿	Ensuring the mechanical integrity of operating equipment through routine maintenance and inspection; and
¿	Investigating all incidents that could have resulted in a major release or accident.

Should an emergency arise

es to the RMP regulations (December 2018), modifications were made to the collection of the Incident Investigation data.  In the past, we reported all investigations per unit.  However, the regulations became pin-pointed on catastrophic releases or near misses of catastrophic releases.  Therefore, the majority of the units no longer have Incident Investigations data provided.
* Finally, per the December 2018 RMP regulations, the refinery collected information regarding Inherent Safety technology and design updates (68.175(e)(7)). The RMPeSubmit program did not have a location to include this information for Program 3 process units. If the USEPA requires this information, we will be readily able to provide data that was collected as part of this September 2019 resubmission.

bogging situations, alarms, and procedures on how to properly recover from a bogging instance. 
¿	In the interest of Inherent Safety Technology, the refinery is in the process of significantly reducing our inventory of anhydrous ammonia. The project will modify the way the refinery recovers ammonia from our sour water and reduce the largest inventory vessel so the Worst Case Scenario offsite impact will be reduced from 1.7 miles in radius down to less than half a mile in radius.
¿	Our Technical organization completed the relief studies for the entire refinery in 2018.  From those studies, deficiencies in our relief systems were identified and risk ranked according to industry standards.  The refinery is in the process of implementing the mitigation plans for the various process units and addressing the highest risk areas as a priority.  
¿	The refinery leadership has implemented a program to increase awareness and knowledge of high consequence scenarios and activities throughout the refinery.  All workgroups in the refinery (maintenance, operations, technical, contractors, support staff) have engaged in, or will be engaging soon, in activities that highlight the safeguards that are in place to prevent or mitigate an incident from a high consequence scenario in a process unit, or a high consequence activity in the field (Lock-out/Tag-out, Confined space entry, etc.).  The purpose is to have all workers in the refinery aware of the safeguards, and to assure they are in place and functioning.

1.8	Changes from Previous RMP Submittal

* Based on input from the USEPA Consent Decree with Chevron USA, the four sections of the FCC process unit that were previously reported were consolidated under the FCC Unit and GSS in this RMP.  The same approach was used to consolidate the Alky unit with LPG Distribution and Yard DIB, and the three sections of the Isomax (CKN, ISO and Boosters)were combined into the new Isomax process (Plants 5, 6 and 9). 
* Based on the updat

pheric conditions and a rapid release rate. The offsite consequences are determined as the distances where the released substances can reach their endpoints.  For toxic substances the endpoints are defined as the concentrations that represent the maximums at which the agency believes that nearly all people could be exposed for up to one hour without serious or irreversible health effects.  For flammable substances, the endpoint is defined as a one pound per square inch (1 psi) overpressure caused by an explosion of the released vapor cloud.  One psi is sufficient to break windows.  Since these worst-cases scenarios are based on extreme conditions, they are highly unlikely to occur.  Two worst-case scenarios are presented to represent the regulated toxic substances and one for regulated flammable substances handled at the refinery.  

The alternative-case scenarios are presented as, although still unlikely, more realistic scenarios that could occur under abnormal conditions.  One alternative release scenario is analyzed for each of the toxic substances registered in the RMP, and one alternative release scenario is presented for all flammable substances.

1.4	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps
  
As discussed above, the refinery has been working with a PSM program under OSHA since the early 1990's.  The EPA recognized this OSHA process in the development of the RMP program.  The OSHA program satisfies the RMP requirements for a prevention program.  The refinery's PSM program elements include:

¿	Process Safety Information
¿	Process Hazards Analysis
¿	Operating Procedures
¿	Training
¿	Mechanical Integrity
¿	Management of Change
¿	Pre-startup Safety Review
¿	Compliance Audits
¿	Incident Investigation
¿	Employee Participation
¿	Hot Work Permits
¿	Contractors

The facility has fully implemented these elements under the OSHA standard. Additional prevention steps specific to ammonia include refinery specifications for

new piping and equipment in ammonia service.  These specifications exceed most typical requirements for oil-handling equipment due to the unique hazards of ammonia.  The specifications include features such as having high reliability valves, minimal connections, using heat treated metals in vessels, selection of metals resistant to embrittlement during auto-refrigeration, and more isolation valves on liquid lines.

1.5	Five Year Accident History

There have been no incidents to report that fit the five-year criteria.


1.6	Emergency Response Program

The refinery maintains a full-time fire department with equipment that meets the needs of responding to refinery fires and releases of chemicals, technical rescues and emergency medical situations.  An emergency response plan has been developed to address the following:

¿	Specific actions to take in a response to an accidental release of hazardous chemicals;
¿	Procedures for informing the public and the local agencies;
¿	Information on emergency health care;
¿	Information on how to communicate with the local emergency response agency;
¿	Identification, maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency equipment; and
¿	Training information.

This plan was developed in consultation with, and final approval by the local fire department.  The refinery fire fighters and emergency response personnel routinely drill and train to maintain their skills in emergency response.


1.7	Planned Changes to Improve Safety


The refinery continually looks for and capitalizes on opportunities to improve safety.  This section provides several examples of safety initiatives relevant to the RMP and general employee safety.
¿	The refinery is evaluating all process units that include a furnace in order to prevent bogging.  The approach includes: a refinery subject matter expert who can provide training, new and refresher training of our operators, installation of independent CO and O2 analyzers to improve detection of
